skill.name: azure-prepare
skill.description: Default entry point for Azure application development. Invoke this skill for ANY application work related to Azure: creating apps, building features, adding components, updating code, migrating, or modernizing. Analyzes your project and prepares it for Azure deployment by generating infrastructure code (Bicep/Terraform), azure.yaml configuration, and Dockerfiles. USE FOR: create an app, build a web app, create API, create frontend, create backend, add a feature, build a service, make an application, develop a project, migrate my app, modernize my code, update my application, add database, add authentication, add caching, deploy to Azure, host on Azure, Azure with Terraform (defaults to azd+Terraform), Azure with azd, generate azure.yaml, generate Bicep or Terraform, prepare Azure Functions. DO NOT USE FOR: only validating an already-prepared app (use azure-validate), only running azd up/deploy (use azure-deploy), pure Terraform without azd (prefer azd+Terraform).
skill.summary: Default entry point for Azure application development. Invoke this skill for ANY application work re...
skill.author: microsoft

security_audit.summary: Security evaluation confirms this is a legitimate Microsoft Azure development skill. Static findings are false positives: external_commands are documented examples of Azure CLI/Terraform commands, not actual execution; sensitive data findings reference standard Azure credential paths for context; weak crypto findings appear in infrastructure template examples; system reconnaissance is for legitimate environment detection.

content.value_statement: Automate Azure infrastructure preparation with intelligent planning, multi-IaC support (Bicep/Terraform), and security hardening for cloud-native applications.
actual_capabilities: Analyze project structure and determine deployment requirements
Generate infrastructure code using Bicep or Terraform templates
Create azure.yaml configuration for Azure Developer CLI
Apply security best practices and hardening to infrastructure
Support multiple deployment recipes: AZD, AZCLI, Bicep, Terraform
limitations: Does not execute deployment - only prepares infrastructure
Requires user approval before generating artifacts
Does not validate existing infrastructure (use azure-validate)
Does not run azd commands directly (use azure-deploy)

use_cases.title: New Azure Application Setup
use_cases.description: Create a new web application with full Azure infrastructure including App Service, Cosmos DB, and networking.

use_cases.title: Existing App Modernization
use_cases.description: Analyze and modernize legacy applications for Azure cloud deployment with appropriate services.

use_cases.title: Infrastructure Template Generation
use_cases.description: Generate production-ready Bicep or Terraform templates for Azure resources with security hardening.

prompt_templates.title: Basic App Deployment
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me prepare my Node.js application for Azure deployment. I want to use Azure App Service with a Cosmos DB backend.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-Service Architecture
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an Azure infrastructure plan for a microservices application with API Gateway, multiple containerized services, event hub, and SQL database.

prompt_templates.title: Modernization Assessment
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze my legacy .NET application and create a modernization plan for Azure Container Apps with appropriate services.

prompt_templates.title: Terraform Infrastructure
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate Terraform templates for an Azure infrastructure with AKS cluster, Azure SQL, Key Vault, and CDN.

output_examples.input: Prepare my Python Flask API for Azure deployment with PostgreSQL
output_examples.output: Plan created with Azure App Service, PostgreSQL Flexible Server, VNet integration, and security hardening. Ready for review.

output_examples.input: Generate Bicep templates for an AKS cluster with ingress
output_examples.output: Infrastructure code generated with AKS, AGIC, Azure DNS, and Key Vault integration.

output_examples.input: Modernize my Java Spring Boot app for cloud
output_examples.output: Analysis complete. Recommended Azure Spring Apps with Cosmos DB, key vault secrets, and CI/CD pipeline.

best_practices: Always review the generated plan before approval to ensure correct resource selection
Use the plan-first workflow to understand all infrastructure changes before execution
Invoke azure-validate after azure-prepare to verify infrastructure before deployment
anti_patterns: Skipping the planning phase and generating infrastructure without approval
Using azure-prepare for validation instead of azure-validate
Deploying directly without validation - always run azure-validate first

faq.question: What is the difference between azure-prepare and azure-deploy?
faq.answer: azure-prepare creates infrastructure code and configuration (plan, Bicep/Terraform, Dockerfiles). azure-deploy actually executes the deployment to Azure.

faq.question: Can I use this skill with pure Terraform?
faq.answer: Yes, you can select Terraform as the recipe during planning. The skill defaults to AZD + Terraform but supports pure Terraform workflows.

faq.question: Does this skill execute any commands on my system?
faq.answer: No, azure-prepare only generates infrastructure code and configuration files. It does not execute any deployment commands.

faq.question: What IaC tools are supported?
faq.answer: The skill supports Bicep, Terraform, Azure CLI, and Azure Developer CLI (AZD) as deployment recipes.

faq.question: Do I need Azure credentials to use this skill?
faq.answer: Credentials are only needed during the deployment phase (azure-deploy). azure-prepare analyzes your project locally.

faq.question: What happens after azure-prepare completes?
faq.answer: You must invoke azure-validate to check the infrastructure, then azure-deploy to actually provision resources in Azure.
